1023792787508977666.text: At the core of good AR apps is computer vision. We can get our machines to recognize scenes like never before. This is completely different from VR, which is about totally reconceptualizing space. VR is about construction of something new.

1126225698354417664.text: One hope I have for spatial computing: that as digital objects enter our lives in ways that feel real and solid, we'll have more desire for reliable craft software. Less about scale, more about quality and purpose. More recognition that software is a thing worth paying for.

1125219222437543937.text: But for a voice assistant in the home, visuals are helpful. The limitation are instead tied to the hardware—especially if your tech is licensed to third parties. I get it: it's hard to justify an entire visual pattern language for Alexa if Sonos can't support it, eg.

1125218441403568129.text: For phone calls, the limitation is the medium itself (and obviously, folks now often choose video calls).

1125218438316560385.text: Eg, for driving and phone calls: both require audio output, but for different reasons. Driving takes up human visual and physical inputs and outputs, so audio is all you got left to work with.

1125218437179920384.text: In reality, there's no need for the whole modality loop to always be audio; it could instead easily be voice in -> visuals out. Just depends on the type of computer and task.

1125218435875495937.text: I wonder too if this is related to voice input historically being portrayed as being so very tied to anthropomorphic AI. If you can talk to your computer surely it can talk back, and ideally with some amount of personality.

1125216325398175745.text: Not to pick on Apple: these are basically best in class examples, actually.

1125167023984599040.text: But this lack of visual modality has hamstrung voice input pretty hard. Users don't know what they can do in the first place, nor do they know why something went wrong. It's mostly guesswork, encouragement and hints:pic.twitter.com/0IrW5eGETd

1125167015692386304.text: It's too bad that most voice input systems have so little visual feedback. This is partly a hardware cost issue, partly habit (telephones and radio traditionally didn't have visual UI attached to the audio output).

1125167014069170177.text: Voice is interesting as it's ubiquitous now via OS-level intergrations, but it is not so popular with users. When it is used, it tends to be a small subset of possible actions: ones users have tried and know have an acceptable error rate, like checking the weather.

1119620652611162112.text: Conventional calendars are great for showing things that happen in multiples of seven, but that's it. Even in the month view gets sloppy fast; you're better off noting dates than using visual pattern recognition.

1119620651042529282.text: Why do I want this? Well, Let's say you had a recurring thing happen every 18 days. On regular calendar views this would look fairly arbitrary, even if it happened like clockwork. I'd have to do math or pay special attention to notice the dates are similar month to month.

1119620648429477890.text: It's crazy to me that we don't have more flexible calendar views. Trying to map out patterns on a seven-days-a-line view isn't always sensible. And yet, afaik there is no calendaring app anywhere that lets you customize or play with data in different grid patterns.

The downside is, of course, that we are narrowing down on what can be expressed in what way. We're not reacting to real humans reacting: we are recognizing a trope.

I'm agnostic about this, but it certainly is interesting.

1106787367774412800.text:
When every performance is the best possible performance, a meme-like performance, an Oscar-worthy performance, we double down on that *interaction* being the expression of that *thought*. 

Meme-worthy stuff hits in just the right spot. Feels real good. We emote immediately.

1106787367170392064.text:
And of course, rage faces paved the way for a similar crystallization of human expression in emoji. Now we have . What a tiny fantastic expression of something that would otherwise take many words to explain. 

This is an interesting uptick in human literacy of _reactions_ .

1106787364918030336.text: This crystallization of performances down to their essence reminds me of rage comics, which are essentially tiny snippets of human expression that are so familiar they instantly resonate with huge swathes of humanity.pic.twitter.com/k7VoGWdLQI

Now we have entire affordance schema—a full language—that fill our daily lives with elevator beeps, email send swooshes, police sirens, the quiet ding to stand after an airplane lands, doorbells, payment confirmation beeps. 

The list goes on and on, and we understand it well.

1105220012157988865.text:
A fascinating revelation: humans are now literate in the language of man-made sounds. Think alarms, dings, horns, beeps, mechanical hums.

1103431032617857024.text:
But in the end, even when computers are tiny chips, free from almost all physical hardware sizes & location constraints, you're still interacting with a computer. 

That's why I like spatial computing: it reminds us of what's actually happening. It grounds us in the medium.

1103431032026497024.text:
These computers are getting better, of course, with more sensors, and more ability to take in sensor data and execute on it concurrently with robust apps running at the same time. 

Eventually, we *will* get to that beautiful blend of real world + digital magic.

1103431031443513345.text: When the reality is: when you put on a headset you are putting on two tiny projectors shooting light into your eyeballs in a way that tricks you into thinking 2D frames are 3D. What powers this is a pretty fast, probably small, but still technically possible computer.

1103431030914990080.text: And so people put on a device assuming they are not interacting with a *regular* computer anymore, but a somehow more advanced computer, one that understands them better—one that mimics the laws of the human world, but has a perfect blend of intuitive digital magic.

1103431030185181184.text:
Some thoughts on why I started to prefer the term 'spatial computing' to ' [x] reality' last year. 

There is an assumption (in pop culture, in people's minds, in media) that AR/VR/MR are...well, other realities. Digital, sure, but more 'real' than dealing with a computer today.

Therefore, the whole spectrum of how men treated women was declared to be inconsequential compared to the rest of their actions, immune to moral judgement.

Here are the five rules of computer input popularity. In order to hit scale, the inputs must be:

- cheap
- reliable
- comfortable
- have enough software that makes use of it, and
- have an acceptable user error rate.

There are lots of variables, but these are the big five.
